questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: She is a very talent girl.
She is a very talented girl.
She is a very talents girl.
She is a very talenting girl.
questions.explanation: The correct adjective form is 'talented', not 'talent'.

questions.question: Choose the correct order of adjectives:
options: He bought a red small new car.
He bought a new small red car.
He bought a small new red car.
He bought a new red small car.
questions.explanation: Typical adjective order is opinion/size + age + color + noun: 'small new red car'.

questions.question: Select the correct comparative form:
options: This problem is more easy than that one.
This problem is easier than that one.
This problem is easyer than that one.
This problem is most easy than that one.
questions.explanation: One‑syllable adjectives like 'easy' usually take '-er': 'easier'.

questions.question: Select the correct superlative form:
options: She is the most tall girl in the class.
She is the taller girl in the class.
She is the tallest girl in the class.
She is the most tallest girl in the class.
questions.explanation: For short adjectives like 'tall', use 'the + adjective + est': 'the tallest'.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: This soup tastes well.
This soup tastes good.
This soup is tasting goodly.
This soup is very well taste.
questions.explanation: After sense verbs like 'taste', use an adjective, not an adverb: 'tastes good'.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: He became angrily when he heard the news.
He became anger when he heard the news.
He became angry when he heard the news.
He became more angryly when he heard the news.
questions.explanation: Linking verbs like 'become' are followed by adjectives: 'became angry'.

questions.question: Select the correct option to complete the sentence: 'This is the ______ movie I have ever seen.'
options: more boring
most boring
boringest
very boring
questions.explanation: With 'ever' and a superlative, use 'the most boring'.

questions.question: Select the correct sentence:
options: She speaks an excellent English.
She speaks excellent English.
She speaks a excellent English.
She speaks the excellent English.
questions.explanation: When a noun is uncountable like 'English', use 'excellent English' without an article.

questions.question: Choose the correct form:
options: This exercise is too much difficult.
This exercise is very too difficult.
This exercise is much difficult.
This exercise is too difficult.
questions.explanation: 'Too' is followed directly by an adjective: 'too difficult'.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: She is afraid from spiders.
She is afraid of spiders.
She is afraid by spiders.
She is afraid about spiders.
questions.explanation: The correct collocation is 'afraid of' something.

questions.question: Select the correct comparative structure:
options: My house is more big than yours.
My house is bigger than yours.
My house is more bigger than yours.
My house is biggest than yours.
questions.explanation: For one‑syllable adjectives like 'big', use 'bigger', not 'more big' or 'more bigger'.

questions.question: Select the correct sentence:
options: He is interested on history.
He is interested for history.
He is interested about history.
He is interested in history.
questions.explanation: The correct phrase is 'interested in' something.

questions.question: Choose the correct option:
options: This book is enough interesting.
This book is quite interesting.
This book is very enough interesting.
This book is too interesting for me read.
questions.explanation: 'Quite' is commonly used before adjectives in this meaning: 'quite interesting'.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: She looks happily today.
She looks happy today.
She is looking happily today.
She is look happy today.
questions.explanation: 'Look' as a linking verb takes an adjective: 'looks happy'.

questions.question: Select the correct form to complete the sentence: 'This is ______ question than the last one.'
options: a difficult
the more difficult
a more difficult
more difficult
questions.explanation: Before a singular count noun, use 'a more difficult question'.

questions.question: Select the correct sentence:
options: He gave me an useful advice.
He gave me useful advice.
He gave me a useful advices.
He gave me some useful advice.
questions.explanation: 'Advice' is uncountable; use 'some useful advice'.

questions.question: Choose the correct pair:
options: She feels bad and sadly.
She feels badly and sad.
She feels bad and sad.
She feels badly and sadly.
questions.explanation: After 'feel', adjectives are used: 'feels bad and sad'.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: He is responsible of this project.
He is responsible to this project.
He is responsible for this project.
He is responsible about this project.
questions.explanation: The correct phrase is 'responsible for' something.

questions.question: Select the correct form:
options: Today is the most hot day of the year.
Today is the hotest day of the year.
Today is the hottest day of the year.
Today is the more hot day of the year.
questions.explanation: For 'hot', double the final consonant and add '-est': 'the hottest'.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: He is very angry to me.
He is very angry with me.
He is very angry on me.
He is very angry for me.
questions.explanation: The common collocation is 'angry with someone'.

questions.question: Choose the correct option:
options: It was a so boring lecture.
It was so a boring lecture.
It was such a boring lecture.
It was such boring lecture.
questions.explanation: 'Such a/an + adjective + singular noun': 'such a boring lecture'.

questions.question: Select the correct adjective order:
options: He has a wooden beautiful small table.
He has a small beautiful wooden table.
He has a beautiful small wooden table.
He has a small wooden beautiful table.
questions.explanation: Usual order is opinion + size + material + noun: 'beautiful small wooden table'.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: She is married with a doctor.
She is married to a doctor.
She is married by a doctor.
She is married of a doctor.
questions.explanation: The correct phrase is 'married to' someone.

questions.question: Select the correct comparative sentence:
options: This test is less difficult than the previous one.
This test is lesser difficult than the previous one.
This test is more less difficult than the previous one.
This test is little difficult than the previous one.
questions.explanation: 'Less + adjective' is the correct comparative: 'less difficult'.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: The news is very surprising.
The news are very surprising.
The news is very surprised.
The news are very surprised.
questions.explanation: 'News' is singular and takes 'is'; it causes surprise, so 'surprising' is correct.

questions.question: Select the correct form:
options: He is enough tall to play basketball.
He is tall enough to play basketball.
He is enoughly tall to play basketball.
He is so enough tall to play basketball.
questions.explanation: With adjectives, 'enough' comes after the adjective: 'tall enough'.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: This is the most unique idea I have heard.
This is a very unique idea I have heard.
This is the uniqueest idea I have heard.
This is more unique idea I have heard.
questions.explanation: Adjectives like 'unique' are absolute; avoid 'most unique' and use modifiers like 'very unique'.

questions.question: Choose the correct option:
options: He is good in solving problems.
He is good at solving problems.
He is good on solving problems.
He is good for solving problems.
questions.explanation: The correct phrase is 'good at' doing something.

questions.question: Select the correct sentence:
options: She is extremely a smart person.
She is an extremely smart person.
She is a extremely smart person.
She is extremely smart a person.
questions.explanation: Adverb + adjective + noun with article: 'an extremely smart person'.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: I am tired to walking.
I am tired for walking.
I am tired of walking.
I am tired by walking.
questions.explanation: The correct phrase is 'tired of' doing something.
